ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course? (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I really improved my critical thinking and analysis skills, and it made me contemplate immigration and related issues in an entirely new light.
Writing a long essay, analyzing complicated texts, learning about immigration.

I learned so much in this course -- Professor Mukhopadhyay was an engaging discussion leader and helped guide us through the literature in a thoughtful way. I became a better writer and thinker, and I gained a deep understanding of the various writings about immigration, and what these diverging forms can teach us.
I gained a better understanding of modern immigration literature, particularly expanding beyond any traditional definition. I also had the opportunity to improve my writing while doing so.

Ah! I couldnt begin to explain all of the insight and knowledge Ive gained from this course. The reading list was absolutely incredible, and Professor Mukhopadhyay is so knowledgeable. This is such an incredible course if not the most incredible Ive taken at Yale. I learned how to read and analyze postcolonial theory & write about it succinctly and in a research format. If you want to be able to understand and analyze immigration and critical immigration theory, this is the best course to do it.
I felt like my close reading abilities grew strongly as a result of this class. The final research paper along with Prof. Mukhopadhyays guidance helped me grow as a literature student immensely.
Leading discussion, reading across mediums

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved? (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments:
Strengths: great discussion and great book selection! I always really enjoyed the questions brought forth in class (although some were a bit hard to think about the spot).  
Weaknesses: this is not a weakness per se, but it was a senior seminar and I am generally used to slightly more structured writing assignments. I got used to it over time, but there is a bit of a learning curve.
Pretty much everything in this class was a strength from Professor Mukhopadhyay to the reading list.

Strengths: discussion was engaging, we read amazing materials

Weaknesses: reliance on student presentations resulted in some lags in discussion
I didnt feel like it had any! I loved every minute.

Strength: amazing professor and phenomenal readings (like novels you actually WANT to read) and a great group of students 

Weakness: not really any that come to mind
Strength is the diversity of literature (medium and location), discussions went well. There could perhaps be some more guidance with leading discussion

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: All of the Zoom stuff was as good as Zoom stuff can be!
The seminar functioned as well as possible under virtual circumstances.
Again, Professor Mukhopadhyay knew how to keep the class engaged with really intellectual and insightful discussions. No complaints!
Good large group discussion, breakout rooms could be incorporated

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Yes, I would! I wasn't sure what to expect coming into the course, but I know that coming out of the course, I can now think more critically about the issues surrounding immigration.
Yes! Amazing course for anyone interested in reading about immigration in literature. Wonderful class discussions with an amazing professor!
Yes, absolutely -- to any student interested in immigration or postcolonial studies, this class is a must-take.
To any student interested in the syllabus and expanding their definition of immigration literature.

Absolutely! I feel like the rest of my survey was telling, but this was just a mindblowingly incredible course. I learned so much, read absolutely incredible writers that arent in conventional syllabi, and have a newfound appreciation for the depth and complexity of immigration.
Absolutely!! Prof. Mukhopadhyay is a very understanding, kind, and engaging, and she made this course 100% worth it. Definitely one of the best seminars Ive been in.
YES!
